title: Fight which led to teen being brutally stabbed to death in the street
text:

This is the vicious doorway fight which led to a teenage youth mentor being brutally stabbed to death in the street.

Hamed Hussein, now 19, repeatedly stabbed Jordan Moazami in Harborne, Birmingham, after a row over drugs and money sparked at the home of a mutual friend.

Police have released CCTV footage, shown during the court trial, of the moment the disagreement broke out between the 18-year-old victim and his friend on Blandford Road on April 23 this year.

Witnesses recall seeing the group fight - shown above - erupt a short time later, with Mr Moazami and Moshood Giwa scrapping with others in the front garden.

The brawl spills into the street as Jordan throws off his shirt.

(Image: BPM MEDIA)

(Image: BPM MEDIA)

He then flees in a Vauxhall Corsa, but violence then flares in Tennal Road, Harborne - where the 18-year-old was knifed in the hand while trying to defend himself from the killer.

He ran for his life, but was chased to his death and stabbed fatally four times in the back. His mother and members of the public rushed to his aid and medics tried to save his life, but he was sadly pronounced dead at the scene.

Hussein and Giwa were captured running across a junction on a driver's dashcam and moments later, the callous killer was filmed calmly walking into an Indian restaurant at the end of the street.

With Jordan's blood still on his trainers, Hussein is seen heading inside Vaibhavam and speaking to a member of staff, but he appears to be turned away.

Hussein, who was 18 at the time of the murder, has today been caged following a trial by jury at Birmingham Crown Court .

He was found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum term of 19 years.

As he was escorted down to his cell, Jordan's family and friends hurled abuse at the killer, screaming: "Ugly, evil murdering c***" , "scum", "murderer" and "ugly b***".

Judge Melbourne Inman QC said in passing sentence: "Jordan Moazami was only 18 when he died, he had his life before him. Sadly this is another case where the carrying of knives by young men has escalated violence to murder.

"This was a Wednesday evening in a residential road. There was a dispute between Giwa and Moazami which was a drugs dispute.

"It is clear that Mr Moazami pursued you in a car. You were prepared for violence and willing to fight. The knife has never been recovered. It was clearly a formidable knife.

"You chased and attacked Mr Moazami. You struck at least five blows with a knife. The fatal blow was properly described as brutal. The sentence is fixed by law and is one of custody for life.

"Although you have a relevant conviction you do not have any previous convictions for serious violence.

"You come from a good family. You were not the initial aggressor. There is a degree of provocation.

"You responded to violence. To that extent it was not premeditated.

"You had gone out that day with a fearsome weapon if violence should occur. I sentence you to custody to life. The appropriate minimum term is 19 years."

Giwa, who was on trial for manslaughter, was cleared and discharged on the same day.

Jordan’s mother paid tribute to him and thanked the community for their support: “Jordan will never be forgotten, he will be remembered through his family, friends and all those whose lives he touched.

“I'd like to thank everybody that helped bring Jordan's killer to justice and thank the local community for their continuing support.”
description: Jordan Moazami, 18, was knifed while trying to defend himself from his killer Hamed Hussein during the attack in April
